July 31, 2025: Charlotte Roullier is awarded the 2025 European Society for Photobiology (ESP) best thesis award (ESP2hD). Congratulations, Charlotte!“Receiving the ESP2hD award is a meaningful milestone in my scientific journey: I am deeply grateful for the recognition it represents for my PhD research in biophotovoltaics but also for the potential of new sustainable biotechnologies in the energy transition.This distinction also brings a valuable opportunity to exchange with the wide ESP community and to engage in fruitful collaborations.”Learn more about it here:https://www.photobiology.eu/esp-best-phd-thesis-award

August 4, 2017: Press release titled, “Building a nanotube biosensor” interviews Edward Honein on his summer project in the lab.“In our applications we use semiconducting nanotubes that have a specifc energy barrier, called the ‘band gap’,” says Honein. “When we excite the nanotubes with a laser, an electron is excited across this barrier into the conductance band. Eventually this electron relaxes, and in doing so releases a photon – which is what we see as emitted light.”Learn more about it here:https://actu.epfl.ch/news/building-a-nanotube-biosensor/
